abstracts.cdata!:
Coming out of a costly decade-long civil
            war in the 1980s, El Salvador has experienced substantial
            progress in terms of its economic and social performance.
            Poverty levels were reduced from around 65 percent at the
            beginning of the 1990s to 35.5 percent in 2007. Through
            lending and non-lending operations, the International Bank
            for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) has accompanied
            this process and continues supporting the country's
            economic and social agenda. During the recent global crisis,
            El Salvador was seriously affected due to its strong
            linkages with the United States (U.S.) economy. As a result,
            the Salvadoran economy suffered a historic recession and
            poverty gains were partially lost. The Bank and other
            multilaterals became critical partners in confronting such a
            difficult period.
